etymologies: Old English grunnettan, of Germanic origin and related to German grunzen; probably originally imitative

definitions: (of an animal, especially a pig) make a low, short guttural sound

examples.text: an enormous pig grunted and shuffled in a sty outside

definitions: (of a person) make a low inarticulate sound, typically to express effort or indicate assent

examples.text: he grunted his approval and then walked back
Graham grunted and heaved as he helped the masons fit a huge slab of stone into place

definitions: a low, short guttural sound made by an animal or a person

examples.text: with snorts and grunts the animals were coaxed down the ramp
he answered with a grunt and made no further reply

definitions: a low-ranking or unskilled soldier or other worker
etymologies: alteration of ground, from ground man (with reference to unskilled railway work before progressing to lineman)

examples.text: he went from grunt to senior executive vice president in less than five years

definitions: an edible shoaling fish of tropical inshore waters and coral reefs, able to make a loud noise by grinding its teeth and amplifying the sound in the swim bladder.

notes.text: Family Pomadasyidae: numerous genera and species

definitions: a dessert made of fruit topped with dough
shortDefinitions: dessert made of fruit topped with dough
